American troops are gone from Iraq and they are leaving Afghanistan, but thousands who served with the American military are still left behind.

forces risk retaliation when those forces leave.
Congress passed laws to grant U.S.
visas to these allies, but the process is slow.

Quil spoke with Army Captain Matt Zeller here in Washington, and he reached the translator, Janis Shinwari, in Kabul, Afghanistan.
Matt Zeller served in 2008 on a remote base in eastern Afghanistan.
His translator, Janis Shinwari, was his window to the world outside the wire.
One of the first thing he said to me is he said you are a guest in my country and I am now honor-bound.
I'm obligated to make sure that you go home safely.

On April 28, 2008, Zeller was on a patrol near a village controlled by the Taliban.
They got directed by a local farmer down the wrong road into a trap.
Janis Shinwari was back at base.
He heard what happened on the radio.
Their unit were on a mission and on the way back their one truck was hit by an IED and the second truck was hit by an RPG.

We were taking fire from the village itself, the periphery of this village.
